docs.abstract: This almond cake is just right for indulging in the Swedish ritual of coffee, sweets and conversation.
docs.snippet: This almond cake is just right for indulging in the Swedish ritual of coffee, sweets and conversation.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Coffee and” was an expression I heard all the time as a kid. From early morning until late in the afternoon, the aroma that filled the kitchen, wafted through the living room and wisped its way up the stairs was coffee, Chock Full o’ Nuts specifically. The coffeepot burbled steadily in our house, always ready for the next cup, and at least once a day, one or another of my mom’s friends would knock on the unlocked door, push it open and head for the kitchen, knowing that the percolator would be on the stove and that on the counter there would be cake — the “and” in “coffee and.”

headline.main: The Perfect Cake for Your Coffee Break
headline.print_headline: The Perfect Cake for Your Coffee Break

docs.abstract: The lyrical passages in Meena Alexander’s eloquent final book track her lifetime of far-flung journeys, crisscrossing the globe, from her own childhood in Kerala, India, to Venice and Manhattan.
docs.snippet: The lyrical passages in Meena Alexander’s eloquent final book track her lifetime of far-flung journeys, crisscrossing the globe, from her own childhood in Kerala, India, to Venice and Manhattan.
docs.lead_paragraph: We come together in crowds so regularly, as strangers finding our ways — consider how immigrants do this more often and better than anyone, wanting to blend, be made invisible graciously. The lyrical passages in Meena Alexander’s eloquent final book track her lifetime of far-flung journeys, crisscrossing the globe, from her own childhood in Kerala, India, to Venice and Manhattan. New York City presides as destination of brave generations, who quickly learn its neighborhoods and alleyways, the idiosyncrasies of acceptance and the richest identity of mingling. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

byline.original: By Meena Alexander and Naomi Shihab Nye

docs.abstract: He’d had episodes of coughing and wheezing since he was a boy. Now in his 60s, he worried his symptoms would force him to quit working.
docs.snippet: He’d had episodes of coughing and wheezing since he was a boy. Now in his 60s, he worried his symptoms would force him to quit working.
docs.lead_paragraph: The 65-year-old man collapsed into the driver’s seat of his car in a small town outside Philadelphia. He could hear his breath: ragged, wheezy and fast, interrupted by a relentless cough. Winter was always bad for his breathing, but that year had been particularly hard, and that morning felt more difficult than usual. Just walking from his house to his car left him gasping for air as if he had sprinted the short distance.

headline.main: He Had Trouble Breathing, and Inhalers Didn’t Help. What Was Going On?
headline.print_headline: He Had Trouble Breathing, and Inhalers Didn’t Help. What Was Going On?

docs.abstract: Use reindeer peer pressure — harness and lead the dominant bulls. Prepare for long hours in subfreezing temperatures.
docs.snippet: Use reindeer peer pressure — harness and lead the dominant bulls. Prepare for long hours in subfreezing temperatures.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Reindeer need a lot of space,” says Issat Turi, 40, an indigenous Sami reindeer herder from Guovdageaidnu, a Norwegian village north of the Arctic Circle. Every winter, Turi and his extended family look after 1,000 reindeer as they graze freely for lichen under the snow on the tundra. In early spring, the family rounds up the animals, loads them into trucks and drives them 300 miles farther north to an island called Reinoya, where the animals birth their calves by the sea.

docs.abstract: For Jeff Sessions, Roy Moore and other Republicans vying for a chance to take back Doug Jones’s seat, winning over voters may mean winning over the president first.
docs.snippet: For Jeff Sessions, Roy Moore and other Republicans vying for a chance to take back Doug Jones’s seat, winning over voters may mean winning over the president first.
docs.lead_paragraph: In early November, President Trump announced he would be traveling to Tuscaloosa, Ala., to attend the University of Alabama-Louisiana State University football game. When Representative Bradley Byrne, a three-term congressman and United States Senate candidate from Mobile, learned of this plan, he immediately called an Alabama booster named Jim Wilson, who would be hosting Trump in his luxury box near midfield at Bryant-Denny Stadium. Wilson, as fortune would have it, is a distant relative, friend and financial supporter of Byrne’s, and Byrne thought perhaps he could get him into the box.

headline.main: How Alabama’s Senate Primary Became a Trump Loyalty Contest

docs.abstract: For hundreds of years, enslaved people were bought and sold in America. Today most of the sites of this trade are forgotten. As part of The 1619 Project, we photographed 12 of them.
docs.snippet: For hundreds of years, enslaved people were bought and sold in America. Today most of the sites of this trade are forgotten. As part of The 1619 Project, we photographed 12 of them.
docs.lead_paragraph: For hundreds of years, enslaved people were bought and sold in America. Today most of the sites of this trade are forgotten. As part of The 1619 Project, we photographed 12 of them.

docs.abstract: He met her while doing rounds at the hospital where they both worked. Within months, he received orders to report for basic training.
docs.snippet: He met her while doing rounds at the hospital where they both worked. Within months, he received orders to report for basic training.
docs.lead_paragraph: I was 26 when I was sent to Vietnam, along with 2.7 million men and women of my generation. As an infantry battalion surgeon, I cared for soldiers’ wounds and helped treat their pain — but for me, going to war was also tied to the distress of leaving my first love. I was a doctor and she was a licensed practical nurse at a hospital in Hartford, Conn. Our work had brought us together. Going to war would break us apart.

headline.main: An Army Doctor’s First Loss of the Vietnam War: The Woman He Loved

docs.abstract: Using a much-loved piece of clothing as a duster can be a source of considerable happiness — and an antidote to a lifestyle of galloping consumption.
docs.snippet: Using a much-loved piece of clothing as a duster can be a source of considerable happiness — and an antidote to a lifestyle of galloping consumption.
docs.lead_paragraph: My parents repaired everything when I was a kid. My dad fixed mechanical stuff (car, bikes, plumbing) while my mum took care of clothes. She mended my trousers when they got torn from playing football (soccer) in the schoolyard and turned the collars of my and my dad’s shirts, removing and resewing them so that the old, frayed exteriors were hidden from view and replaced by the perfectly preserved interiors. This was consistent with the key economic fact of my parents’ lives: It was never worth their while to pay anyone to do anything they could possibly do themselves.

docs.abstract: Thousands of African-American troops were sent to a defeated Germany to promote democracy, even as they were confined to the social order of Jim Crow.
docs.snippet: Thousands of African-American troops were sent to a defeated Germany to promote democracy, even as they were confined to the social order of Jim Crow.
docs.lead_paragraph: In commemoration of Black History Month, the latest article from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series by The Times that documents lesser-known stories from World War II, focuses on the challenges of black troops stationed in Germany in the aftermath of the war.

headline.main: When Jim Crow Reigned Amid the Rubble of Nazi Germany
headline.kicker: beyond The World War II WE Know
